subject: Re: Testing exceptions
msgSnippet: Pico, previous replies to your question have hopefully given you some guidance in testing exceptions, but i have to raise some questions about your error
messageBody:
Pico, previous replies to your question have hopefully given you some
guidance in testing exceptions, but i have to raise some questions
about your error handling strategy in general...

<warning>
I am going to make a case against checked exceptions. This is a much
discussed topic, and you should be able to find many differing
opinions. For a detailed argument /against/ checked exceptions in
java, see Bruce Eckels article:
http://www.mindview.net/Etc/Discussions/CheckedExceptions
</warning>

--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "Pico Geyer" <picog@s...> wrote:
> ...
>
> try{
> statement1
> statement2
> }
> catch(ExceptionType1 e1){
> System.err.println("The following exception occurred " +
> e1.toString());
> }
>
> I know that this is not a very good way of handling exceptions...
Glad you noticed :)!

> The most obvious solution would be to let the method throw all
> exceptions that are generated.
For argument's sake, lets explore that option...

Here's a question: if you're not going to do anything about an
exception, why bother catching it? And logging doesn't count - it's
mere hand-waving. In fact, here's how i would rate the possible
responses to a typical exception:

1. Catch it and do nothing - if you do this, i /will/ fire you!
2. Catch it and log it - marginally better, but you're still fired.
3. Catch it, log it and rethrow it - you can keep your job, but your
log file will be filled up with the same exception logged repeatedly.
4. Catch it and rethrow it - better, but if so, why catch it in the
first place?

(note that the topmost layers of your code are exempt - they obviously
have to catch all exceptions and at least report them).

If the answer to item 4. is that you have to catch exceptions because
the compiler forces you to, then your problem is the over-use of
checked exceptions.

> The problem is that there are 5 or 6 different types of
> exceptions that this method can generate and
> this seems to make my code very messy.
/Any/ piece of code can raise dozens of exceptions, but you don't have
to respond to most of them because they're /unchecked/. I am curious
why throwing your 5/6 exception makes your code messy - is it because
they are checked?

Consider what happens if you get in the habit of not using checked
exceptions and wrapping any existing checked exceptions with a
RuntimeException:

try {
new FileInputStream(new File("/tmp/temp.txt"));
}
catch (FileNotFoundException e) {
throw new RuntimeException(e);
}

Now the client code isn't /forced/ to write a catch block for the
FileNotFoundException. If the client actually needs to respond to this
particular exception, use a specific extension of RuntimeException.

What you'll often find, however, is that the majority of your code
won't actually care about exceptions, leaving them to propogate up to
your top-level controllers where they can be communicated to users in
some fashion.

I admit i'm presenting an over-simplified view of the problem;
moreover, this attitude towards exception-handling makes most sense
within an environment supported by rigorous and automated unit
testing. Such environments encourage a rather simple strategy for
dealing with exceptions:
* Fix the bug in your code that /caused/ the exception, instead of
writing more code to respond to bad code. *

Sorry if i've gone off on a tangential rant: i don't really have
enough evidence to assume you are suffering from over-use of checked
exceptions. In any case, i hope this is food for thought.

Cheers, lasitha.
